in data centers doing rack and stack and wiring and managing Linux hosts and doing a lot of shell scripting and all

about what servus is and what's funny is my interest in servus pretty much throws
my entire previous career experience out the window um so a little bit of a challenge but I think one of the really
interesting things in the industry and we'll be talking about this more today so why are we here so two different
topics today kind of married together one chat Bots the other serverless we'll start with kind of a brief intro to how
we think about serverless at AWS so when we talk about serverless we talk about services that kind of meet four
different criteria they have to not have anything for you to manage or provision
no instances no physical servers obviously not even containers so we don't consider containers anything that
has to do with serverless they will scale with usage so what this means is that you should never have to say that
you need a certain amount of Widgets or gizmos or instances or anything else in terms of throughput or capacity going
along with this you should never have to pay for idle so if you're never going to have to pre-provision things then you should never have to pay for idle things
that are sitting around being unused and then lastly leave that high availability fault should be built into it so at AWS
we have a concept of regions these are these Geographic locations where we have our infrastructure there's about 16 of
those today around the globe those are then made up of availability zones you can think of them kind of as independent
data centers that are typically within a couple miles of each other such that we typically recommend that customers build
their infrastructure spanning availability zones for high availability and fault tolerance but in the world of
serverless you should never have to think about that planning of where your infrastructure lives it should be
completely taken care of and provided for you another aspect of serverless and
it kind of goes back to the keynote this morning is this concept of event-driven computing and so we've seen event driven
Computing really take off in the last couple years and then what that's LED itself to is this concept called functions as a service by where you
completely decompose your application down into individual functions and those functions are ideally only being
executed at event Trigger Time and providing the value that they do based on what that value based on what that
function does and so in our model at AWS we find the center of that world to be a product
of ours called AWS Lambda and I'll come back to talk about Lambda a little more depth towards the end of this uh session
here today so we consider Lambda to be servess in the sense that it's event driven it's function as a service and it
meets the four prior criteria that I was talking about so you never have to pre-provision it you never have to deal
with scaling it you don't pay for idle um and it has high availability and default tolerance built in to it and
again we'll talk about Lambda and see it in action here a little bit now Lambda is a pretty hot service for us we launched it back in 2014 and what we've
seen is customers doing all sorts of cool things with it so there's a number of different use cases from web backends
to web actual applications chatbots it automation uh Amazon Alexa so the Alexa
is powered by Lambda for its skills largely and then things like data processing which is actually a really really really huge use case for for
Lambda and so today's talk OB obviously we're going to be focusing on the chatbot use case for Lambda and what it
can do to help simplify the backend that you have for your chatbot so enough about Lambda let's
come back to the next topic which is that of chat bots so we've seen over the last I guess just about 10 years now
since the iPhone came out this huge evolution in terms of how we are dealing with interfacing with computer-based
applications so once upon a time we had Punch Cards and then tape based applications eventually we moved on to
gooey based applications pointers sliders you know things that we clicked on and did stuff with and now what we're
finding is that there's a lot of applications that are conversational based and so companies are making use of chat Bots for all sorts of different
things uh whether they be customer support related or sales related or information related uh you've got things
like Pizza Hut which has an app that you can use to order pizza Capital One which has a capability through Amazon Alexa to
check out your bank account status and other banking information uh all sorts of different companies that are using it for support reasons I know
I've used it once to process a return from an e-commerce uh company that I bought something from and so this new
generation of interfaces is very different and so there's some key characteristics that make up this new
world of interfaces again the other ones that you had were very rigid uh Punch Cards being incredibly rigid then moving
on to things like web interfaces where you had certain key buttons certain things you could fill in but now when we
talk about chat Bots we're finding is it's a completely different way of communicating right chat Bots can kind of have a personality to them and we see
this again with things like Alexa with CI that they have kind of a personality that they're known for sometimes you can
ask them things funny things tell me a joke or something like that and they'll respond back and do that and so we see
them being much more natural in terms of the way that you communicate with them ideally much more accessible right so
whether you have uh you speak a different language or you have maybe a certain uh to a language or you live in
the south and you talk someplace or you live in Chicago and you talk really really weird compared to those of us from New York City right there's all
these different things that we want our our chat Bots whether text or verbal based to uh to work for uh on demand so
we don't necessarily know when a chatbot might be used it's a lot more unpredictable when it comes to average
customer load or usage for chapot and then lastly we want these to be very efficient right we want to give people
the information that they're looking for very quickly and they may not necessarily know what they're looking for but we could do things to guide them
in the right direction so I already kind of talked about some of the use cases and there's
just a lot that are out there broken down across kind of four main categories that we see so informational Bots again
things like you land on a website and says hey do you have any questions about what you're seeing here uh application based bots so this is what I kind of
like to lump together into what people today call chat Ops so chat Ops is this new kind of it movement SL functionality
Focus thing where teams are building Bots to help them with things like deployments uh monitoring metrics you
know all sorts of infrastructure related things Enterprise productivity bots so we're seeing companies now building Bots
internally to help with things like processing insurance claims let's say there's a number of different things
that are out there and then Internet of Things Bots and these are typically ones that you don't interface with exactly
the same way as these others but this is things like asking Alexa to turn on the lights or asking Alexa to lower the
blinds right these are kind of different uh ways of interfacing with not a a
computer interface that's going to give you other information but with the world around us in a somewhat physical
way so given all this though there's a lot of challenges typically with Bots um for years people have been making Bots
and typically you have a very pre-programmed interface you're expecting some preset text to be put in
or certain phrases and as you try to get more and more Dynamic of those phrases it requires a lot of interesting
technology to support that right not all of us is going to go into an app like
the Domino Pizza app and order pizza the same way some people might say hey I want a pie hey I want a pizza I'd like a
pepperoni pizza there's all sorts of different things that one could say that would cause the B we would hope to be
able to understand what we're looking for and be able to act upon that then again we've got things like language
differences so a whole number of different kind of things that we'd be looking into that are issues or challenges with traditionally writing
chat bots so so at Amazon we've been working on this problem and you we launched the Alexa a couple years back
and just within the last year actually going back about five months ago now we released a product called Amazon Lex so
Amazon Lex is the uh one of the components that makes up Alexa under the
hood it's responsible for speech recognition and then also for natural language um technology and so with Lex
and we'll show this working here we could build conversational Bots that take some level of us not needing to
build exact programmatic interfaces because it's going to help us understand some of the we call intents and or
tensions around what we want to do with our app and so uh Al sorry Le something
you can go and use today fully manage service for you you don't have to run anything doesn't require any infrastructure on your
side so what are the components of Lex so with Lex there's a couple of
different kind of key terms that we need to know we have an intent which which is kind of the action that we want to take
book a hotel find me a flight order me a pizza launch this instance deploy the
code right that is an intent you think of as an action that you want to execute upon from there then we have utterances
utterances are the things that are used typically to key off an intent or to help fill in information about the
intent then we have slots this is kind of further information so we say I want to launch an instance comes back and
says what kind of instance and you say say I want to launch a large instance or I like to order a pizza what kind of
pizza would you like to order a large pizza would you like any toppings pepperoni so those various options are
what are considered slots and then lastly there's fulfillment of this bot action so this is after we've given our
bot all the information that it needs to do what it needs to do the bot then is going to do that work and execute that
upon us and this is typically where your business logic lives and where it's interfacing with other systems on your side and so forth and so we see this
here is an example in a mobile application uh using
Lex so let's break down a little further what is actually happening here behind the scenes so Lex supports both text and
voice-based input so you can build into your application voice capture and pass it in um or you could just have it be a
text based spot maybe and I'll show an example of this in slack here in a little bit so Lexa is going to take that
audio or that text it's then going to break it down using the speech recognition technology that we have into
the key phrases or key words that are part of uh the input that I sent into it
from here then it's going to use the natural language processing technology that we have in Amazon which again is
the same stuff used behind Alexa behind the scenes to figure out what the intent is of what we're trying to do from here
then it's going to look at the intent and understand okay what Slots of information do I have to fill in about
this this intention that I'm trying to act upon and so we see here that we're trying to book a hotel so we're said
like the book a hotel it's going to come back and ask us some information about what city what checkin what check out
and we have the ability to do things such as validate this information uh provide different options as part of
this so we can call out to things like Lambda which we'll talk a little bit more about later and then at some point we've answered all the questions that
our bot has and then it can go ahead and fulfill this for us so again assuming that we're maybe uh someone like Expedia
or kayak this could be something that could exist on our website you know then we can go down and actually execute on
this intention that I have as a customer or as a user of the spot um poly which
I'm not talking about much at all today is another one of the sibling services to Lex um and Amazon poly is the voice
technology that exists in Alexa and allows it to speak outward uh text that
you sent into it and so you could then have your chatbot if it was a verbal chatbot or an Amazon Alexa skill uh
speak back out the text that's been sent into it so breaking this down again utterances
these are the things that key off our intentions so these are things again like I'd like to book a hotel I want to
make a hotel reservation can you help me make my help me book my hotel and I want to book a hotel in New York City right
these are the actions I want it to take slots then again are the
information about uh the intention basically what is needed for my intention to be fulfilled and so we see

the key in our world for serverless at WS um and we consider a seress
application to be one basically built around it where you have an Event Source you then have your function or functions
and then it completes some sort of an action based on it talking to uh a data source or another API or something that
it might interface with the case of today's example my Event Source is going to be uh Lex in this case calling Lambda

today oh awesome okay I'll go through this as quick as I can for those who are not familiar with Lambda because there
were some people in this room who are not so Lambda is a compute service here at AWS it's a completely managed service
for you where again the idea behind a function as a service platform is to decompose your application into the most
kind of bare primitive functions that you can uh in the case of Lambda we have
a number of different languages that we support So node.js python uh Java and then C a couple
different versions so we just launched Python 3 a week or two ago uh nodejs 6.10 about three weeks before that with
Lambda the only knob that you really tweak is the amount of memory that you want your function to use so today uh we
support from 128 Megs up to one2 gigs there's kind of a correlation between
the amount of CPU power that you get with memory so if you have a very compute intensive task giving it more
memory is the best thing to do and then a timeout and basically with Lambda you pay in hundreds of milliseconds of
execution time and so when an event is triggered such as Lambda or such as Lex calling Lambda we fire up a resource to
run your code we execute your code and then we basically stop building you after it's done with
executing uh in terms of authoring functions so we have a web console which I'll show here in a moment you could use
any IDE we've got a number of development tools and things that interface with it again monitoring and logging or built in um let's skip over
the rest here so one thing that people don't know is that we actually have a little over 20 different event trigger
types for Lambda today um so Lex is just one of them but a lot of our infrastructure tools a lot of our
database Services can all invoke Lambda and so there's a lot of really interesting things that you can do with it and there's kind of three different
models for how those invent triggers can work there's a synchronous model uh
basically where it is going to trigger the Lambda function not wait around for anything to happen there's more of a
synchronous push model such as Lex where it's going to look for a return from Lambda to come back as opposed to just
kind of firing for getting it and then there's the stream pole model which exists with Dynamo Kinesis by which you can actually stream requests through
Lambda and it will process them and then keep on processing more over time um and so depending on your use case and what
you want to do with Lambda these three different models exist again we're going to be focusing on the middle one here which is more of a synchronous model
given that our Lex conversation bot isn't going to want to go back and Poll for some information it's going to want an answer right away from
Lambda and so combining Lambda and Lex is actually really really powerful for chap boots and I'll show this here
working here in a moment um both so again both kind of meet the criteria that we have for servus applications the
scale on demand you never have to think about capacity planning uh you never have to pay for idle and they have fault
